title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 ยง 152.8 - New York State income tax returns for periods of less than 12 months
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 ยง 152.8 - New York State income tax returns for periods of less than 12 months

State Regulations
(a) In the case of
an estate, trust or partnership which was not in existence for the entire 12
months of its normal taxable year, the short period which the taxpayer was in
existence during such 12 months is a taxable year for which a New York State
income tax return must be filed. Examples of such short taxable years are as
follows: (1)

If a partnership is terminated
and completely liquidated during its normal taxable year and this results in an
accounting period of less than 12 months for Federal income tax purposes, such
period is a taxable year for which a New York State partnership return must be
filed. (2)

The first New York State
fiduciary return of an estate or trust will often be a short- period income tax
return, due to the choice of an accounting period by the fiduciary which is
either a calendar year or fiscal year. For an estate, the first New York State
fiduciary return would cover the period from the day following the decedent's
death to the start of the regular tax year selected by the fiduciary; for a
trust, the first New York State fiduciary return would cover the period from
the date the trust was established to the beginning of the trust's regular tax
year, as selected by the trustee. (3)

The final New York State fiduciary return
of an estate or trust will in many situations be a short-period income tax
return, due to the termination of administration with respect to the estate, or
the termination of the trust, during its normal taxable year. (b) In general, the requirements
with respect to the time for filing a short-period income tax return are the
same as for the filing of a New York State income tax return or a taxable year
of 12 months which ends on the last day of the short period; see section
152.1
of this Part. Notes
